body:
<!-- Please use this template while reporting a bug and provide as much info as possible. Not doing so may result in your bug not being addressed in a timely manner. Thanks!

If the matter is security related, please disclose it privately via https://kubernetes.io/security/
-->


**What happened**:
Running the vSphere cloud provider on a windows node throws the following error:
```
E0228 18:07:38.491060    4324 datacenter.go:78] Unable to find VM by UUID. VM UUID: a7ff1742-06d1-549d-712b-193a270b7917
E0228 18:07:38.491060    4324 vsphere.go:1467] Cannot find VM runtime host. Get zone for node ul-win-node-5k error
E0228 18:07:38.491060    4324 kubelet_node_status.go:68] Unable to construct v1.Node object for kubelet: failed to get zone from cloud provider: No VM found
```

This is because the vm identifier is retrieved with the command `wmic csproduct get uuid` - https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/cloudprovider/providers/vsphere/vsphere_util_windows.go#L28, which assumes that the uuid and serial are the same.  On some vmware vm versions, the uuid and serial are not the same.  vmware#450 (comment), vmware#450 (comment)


**What you expected to happen**:
Kubelet is able to find vm in vCenter from the identifier looked up on the node.

`wmic bios get serialnumber` or `wmic csproduct get identifyingnumber` should be used instead to find the vm identifier. 

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:
Issue only occurs on some vm versions, such as 13.  https://github.com/vmware/kubernetes/issues/450#issuecomment-362476499

**Anything else we need to know?**:
On the linux side, this issue was resolved by switching from looking up the id from `/sys/class/dmi/id/product_uuid` to `/sys/class/dmi/id/product_serial`. 
 See https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/59519

Some discussion about this issue here - https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/71147

**Environment**:
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`):
1.14.0-beta.1
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration:
Vsphere
- OS (e.g: `cat /etc/os-release`):
Windows 2019
- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`):
- Install tools:
- Others:

title: vSphere cloud provider on windows and vm uuid lookup
